sections.title: Shorthand
sections.content: Because using the field component in its full form can be verbose and repetitive, all form controls in flux allow you pass a label and a description parameter directly. Under the hood, they will be wrapped in a field with an error component automatically.
examples: <flux:input label="Username" description="This will be publicly displayed." />

sections.title: Class targeting
sections.content:
Unlike other form components, Flux's input component is composed of two underlying elements: an input element and a wrapper div. The wrapper div is there to add padding where icons should go.
This is typically fine, however, if you need to pass classes into the input component and have them directly applied to the input element, you can do so using the class:input attribute instead of simply class:

sections.title: Types
sections.content: Use the browser's various input types for different situations: text, email, password, etc.
examples: <flux:input type="email" label="Email" /><flux:input type="password" label="Password" /><flux:input type="date" max="2999-12-31" label="Date" />

sections.title: File
sections.content: Flux provides a special input component for file uploads. It's a simple wrapper around the native input[type="file"] element.
examples: <flux:input type="file" wire:model="logo" label="Logo"/><flux:input type="file" wire:model="attachments" label="Attachments" multiple />

sections.title: Smaller
sections.content: Use the size prop to make the input's height more compact.

sections.title: Disabled
sections.content: Prevent users from interacting with an input by disabling it.

sections.title: Readonly
sections.content: Useful for locking an input during a form submission.

sections.title: Invalid
sections.content: Signal to users that the contents of an input are invalid.

sections.title: Input masking
sections.content: Restrict the formatting of text content for unique cases by using Alpine's mask plugin

sections.title: Icons
sections.content: Append or prepend an icon to the inside of a form input.
examples: <flux:input icon="magnifying-glass" placeholder="Search orders" /><flux:input icon:trailing="credit-card" placeholder="4444-4444-4444-4444" /><flux:input icon:trailing="loading" placeholder="Search transactions" />

sections.title: Icon buttons
sections.content: Append a button to the inside of an input to provide associated functionality.
examples: <flux:input placeholder="Search orders"> <x-slot name="iconTrailing"> <flux:button size="sm" variant="subtle" icon="x-mark" class="-mr-1" /> </x-slot></flux:input><flux:input type="password" value="password"> <x-slot name="iconTrailing"> <flux:button size="sm" variant="subtle" icon="eye" class="-mr-1" /> </x-slot></flux:input>

sections.title: Clearable, copyable, and viewable inputs
sections.content: Flux provides three special input properties to configure common input button behaviors. clearable for clearing contents, copyable for copying contents, and viewable for toggling password visibility.
examples: <flux:input placeholder="Search orders" clearable /><flux:input type="password" value="password" viewable /><flux:input icon="key" value="FLUX-1234-5678-ABCD-EFGH" readonly copyable />

sections.title: Keyboard hint
sections.content: Hint to users what keyboard shortcuts they can use with this input.

sections.title: As a button
sections.content: To render an input using a button element, pass "button" into the as prop.

sections.title: With buttons
sections.content: Attach buttons to the beginning or end of an input element.
examples: <flux:input.group> <flux:input placeholder="Post title" /> <flux:button icon="plus">New post</flux:button></flux:input.group><flux:input.group> <flux:select class="max-w-fit"> <flux:select.option selected>USD</flux:select.option> <!-- ... --> </flux:select> <flux:input placeholder="$99.99" /></flux:input.group>

sections.title: Text prefixes and suffixes
sections.content: Append text inside a form input.

sections.title: Input group labels
sections.content: If you want to use an input group in a form field with a label, you will need to wrap the input group in a field component.
